<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 100, 550, 115]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International Examinations <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 118, 760, 131]]<|/det|> Cambridge International Advanced Subsidiary and Advanced Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 172, 195, 199]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 170, 248]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 214, 422, 258]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[617, 214, 770, 258]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE
NUMBER
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 170, 291]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 415, 312]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 351]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 360, 367, 371]]<|/det|> No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 392, 388, 404]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 718, 431]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 325, 445]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 503, 460]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 504, 474]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 477, 380, 488]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 503, 256, 514]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 529, 359, 540]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 543, 766, 555]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 569, 605, 580]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 583, 757, 595]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating how the extension \(e\) of an elastic cord depends on the diameter \(d\) of the cord when a force is applied.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 918, 168]]<|/det|>
The student has a number of elastic cords of the same material with different diameters. The elastic cords have circular cross-sections. Each cord has an unstretched length of approximately 50 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 182, 917, 214]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the extension \(e\) and the cross-sectional area \(A\) of the cord are related by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 219, 532, 250]]<|/det|>
\[E = \frac{FL}{Ae}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 259, 918, 291]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) is the Young modulus of the material of the cord, \(F\) is the force applied and \(L\) is the unstretched length of the cord.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 305, 712, 320]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(e\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 320, 662, 336]]<|/det|>
Explain how your results could be used to determine a value for \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 351, 917, 383]]<|/det|>
You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account you should pay particular attention to

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 399, 400, 414]]<|/det|>
· the procedure to be followed,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 420, 415, 434]]<|/det|>
· the measurements to be taken,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 440, 351, 454]]<|/det|>
· the control of variables,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 460, 355, 475]]<|/det|>
· the analysis of the data,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 481, 447, 495]]<|/det|>
· any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating monochromatic light passing through a double slit. Bright and dark fringes are produced on a screen as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 116, 840, 196]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 2.1</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 246, 918, 278]]<|/det|>
The distance \(w\) between 10 bright fringes is measured. The fringe spacing \(P\) between neighbouring bright fringes is then determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 293, 633, 310]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated for light of different wavelengths \(\lambda\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 324, 853, 341]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the fringe spacing \(P\) and the wavelength \(\lambda\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 348, 528, 377]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{P}{D} = \frac{\lambda}{s}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 386, 810, 402]]<|/det|>
where \(D\) is the distance from the double slit to the screen and \(s\) is the slit separation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 416, 146, 434]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 416, 645, 434]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(P\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\lambda\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 448, 500, 464]]<|/det|>
Determine an expression for the gradient.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 649, 918, 666]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 479, 90]]<|/det|> Values of \(\lambda\) and \(w\) are given in Fig. 2.2. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 104, 760, 343]]<|/det|>
\(\lambda /10^{-7}\text {m}\)\(w/\text {mm}\)\(P/\text {mm}\)
4.3\(39.5\pm 0.5\)
4.8\(43.5\pm 0.5\)
5.3\(48.0\pm 0.5\)
5.8\(52.0\pm 0.5\)
6.2\(55.5\pm 0.5\)
6.6\(59.0\pm 0.5\)
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[464, 355, 533, 371]]<|/det|> 
Fig. 2.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 386, 559, 402]]<|/det|>

Calculate and record values of \(P/\text {mm}\) in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 402, 480, 417]]<|/det|>

Include the absolute uncertainties in \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 402, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 433, 525, 450]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(P/\text {mm}\) against \(\lambda /10^{-7}\text {m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 448, 424, 465]]<|/det|>
Include the error bars for \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 448, 920, 466]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 479, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Both lines should be clearly labelled.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 495, 920, 513]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 526, 920, 558]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 789, 920, 806]]<|/det|>

gradient = ...........................................................................[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 917, 104]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a) and (c)(iii), determine the value of \(s\). Include an appropriate unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 120, 399, 135]]<|/det|>
Data: \(D = 2.20 \pm 0.02 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 271, 917, 286]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 301, 181, 319]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 301, 546, 317]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 450, 917, 466]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty in \(s =\) ....................................................... % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 481, 146, 500]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 481, 917, 513]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated using the same double slit but an unknown wavelength \(\lambda\) of light. The distance between 10 fringes \(w\) is measured to be \(35.0 \pm 0.5 \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 528, 660, 545]]<|/det|>
Determine \(\lambda\) . Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 761, 917, 777]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\lambda =\) .....................................................................[2]
